Mischa Spoliansky: Musical Stations from ''Morphium'' to Resistance. Klein aber Kunst 003/4 (2CDs). (Distributed by Bear Family Records. United States contact: Sunshine Music Group, Inc. P.O. Box 2209, Stuart, FL 34995-2209. Telephone: 561/286-5549. Fax: 561/286-5755).

One of the happier trends in Germany today is a renewed interest in the popular entertainment of the Weimar Era. It's seen in recent biographies of performers, museum exhibitions, television programs and compilations of vintage recordings, including this one of music by

p.197

Mischa Spoliansky, published to mark the one hundredth anniversary of his birth in 1898.

Spoliansky, a native Russian, arrived in 1914 in Berlin, where he studied music and supported himself playing piano in cafes and movie theaters. Eventually he worked as pianist in Berlin's two most important cabarets: Max Reinhardt's Schall und Rauch and Trude Hesterberg's Wilde BÃ¼hne. At the latter he met lyricist Marcellus Schiffer, and together they created two critically acclaimed revues: Es liegt in der Luft (It's in the Air) and Rufen Sie Herrn Plim! (Call Mr. Plim! ). By the late 1920s Spoliansky was also known as a composer of numerous, delightfully witty pop tunes, and he was a major figure in popularizing American dance music and jazz in Germany. He became one of Berlin's most important popular music composers, but success came shortly before the Nazis seized power, so his fame was brief. He fled to England and there wrote music for more than one hundred films before his death in 1985. This set, as its title suggests, is a survey of his career, beginning withone of his earliest surviving tunes (morphine was a favorite recreational drug during the Weimar years) and ending with his anti-Nazi work for the BBC.
